paragraph.content: an activity in public done reasonably and in good faith, for academic, artistic, scientific or research purposes or for other purposes in the public interest, including discussions about and expositions of any matter.

def.name: ActivityInPublic
def.leadIn: In this section and section 46, activity in public (公開活動) includes any of the following activities, whether or not the person carrying out the activity is in a public place while carrying out the activity—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any form of communication to the public, including speaking, writing, printing, displaying notices, broadcasting, screening and playing of tapes or other recorded material;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any conduct (not being a form of communication referred to in paragraph (a)) observable by the public, including actions and gestures and the wearing or display of clothing, signs, flags, emblems and insignia;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the distribution or dissemination of any matter to the public.

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person, by any activity, incites hatred towards, serious contempt for, or severe ridicule of, another person (the second-mentioned person) or members of a class of persons, on the ground of the race of the second-mentioned person or the members of the class of persons;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person intentionally incites such hatred, serious contempt or severe ridicule on such ground; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: the activity is an activity in public and consists of threatening physical harm, or inciting others to threaten physical harm—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: towards, or towards any premises or property of, the second-mentioned person or the members of the class of persons; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: towards the premises or property of any other person to which the second-mentioned person or the members of the class of persons have access.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (1)(a), it is immaterial whether a person is actually incited, by an activity, to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: hatred towards;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: serious contempt for; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: severe ridicule of,

subsection.continued: another person or members of a class of persons on the ground of the race of the person or members of the class of persons.

subsection.content: A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable on conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 2 years.

Anything done by a person in the course of the person’s employment is to be treated for the purposes of this Ordinance as done by that person’s employer as well as by that person, whether or not it was done with the employer’s knowledge or approval.

Anything done by a person (the first-mentioned person) as agent for another person (the second-mentioned person) with the authority (whether express or implied, and whether precedent or subsequent) of the second-mentioned person is to be treated for the purposes of this Ordinance as done by the second-mentioned person as well as the first-mentioned person.

In proceedings brought under this Ordinance against any other person in respect of an act alleged to have been done by an employee of that person, it is a defence for that other person to prove that he or she took such steps as were reasonably practicable to prevent the employee from doing that act, or from doing in the course of the employee’s employment acts of that description.
For the avoidance of doubt, it is declared that this section does not apply for the purposes of any criminal proceedings.

section.name: s47A
section.heading: Liability of persons engaging interns and volunteers

subsection.content: This section applies for the purposes of section 24A.
For the avoidance of doubt, this section does not apply for the purposes of any criminal proceedings.

subsection.leadIn: An act done by an intern in the course of an internship is to be treated as an act done—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by the intern; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by the person who engaged the intern for the internship, whether or not the act was done with the knowledge or approval of that person.

subsection.leadIn: In proceedings brought under this Ordinance against a person in respect of an act alleged to have been done by an intern engaged by the person, it is a defence for the person to prove that the person took reasonably practicable steps to prevent the intern—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: from doing that act; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: from doing acts of that description in the course of the internship.

subsection.content: Subsections (6) and (7) apply if a volunteer is engaged by another person to perform volunteer work.

subsection.leadIn: An act done by a volunteer in the course of performing volunteer work is to be treated as an act done—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by the volunteer; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by the person who engaged the volunteer to perform the work, whether or not the act was done with the knowledge or approval of that person.

subsection.leadIn: In proceedings brought under this Ordinance against a person in respect of an act alleged to have been done by a volunteer engaged by the person, it is a defence for the person to prove that the person took reasonably practicable steps to prevent the volunteer—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: from doing that act; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: from doing acts of that description in the course of performing volunteer work.

subsection.content: A person who knowingly aids another person to do an act made unlawful by this Ordinance is to be treated for the purposes of this Ordinance as himself or herself doing an unlawful act of the like description.

For the purposes of subsection (1), an employee or agent for whose act the employer or principal is liable under section 47 (or would be so liable but for section 47(3)) is deemed to aid the doing of the act by the employer or principal.

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (1), if a person who engaged an intern—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is liable under section 47A for an act done by the intern; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: would be liable under section 47A for the act but for section 47A(4),

subsection.continued: the intern is deemed to aid the doing of the act by that person. (Added 8 of 2020 s. 33)

subsection.name: 2B
subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (1), if a person who engaged a volunteer—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is liable under section 47A for an act done by the volunteer; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: would be liable under section 47A for the act but for section 47A(7),

subsection.continued: the volunteer is deemed to aid the doing of the act by that person. (Added 8 of 2020 s. 33)

subsection.leadIn: A person (the first-mentioned person) does not under this section knowingly aid another person (the second-mentioned person) to do an unlawful act if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the first-mentioned person acts on a statement made to him or her by the second-mentioned person that, by reason of any provision of this Ordinance, the act which the first-mentioned person aids would not be unlawful; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it is reasonable for the first-mentioned person to rely on that statement.

subsection.content: A person who knowingly or recklessly makes a statement of the kind referred to in subsection (3)(a) which in a material respect is false or misleading commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 4.

part.name: P6
part.heading: Matters not Affected by Parts 3, 4 and 5

section.name: s49
section.heading: Special measures
section.leadIn: Nothing in Part 3, 4 or 5 renders unlawful an act that is reasonably intended to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: ensure that persons of a particular racial group have equal opportunities with other persons in circumstances in relation to which a provision is made by this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: afford persons of a particular racial group goods or access to services, facilities or opportunities to meet their special needs in relation to—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: employment, education, welfare or clubs; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the provision of premises, goods, services or facilities; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: afford persons of a particular racial group grants, benefits or programmes, whether direct or indirect, to meet their special needs in relation to—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: employment, education, welfare or clubs; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the provision of premises, goods, services or facilities.

subsection.leadIn: Nothing in Part 3, 4 or 5—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is to be construed as affecting a provision to which this subsection applies; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: renders unlawful an act which is done in order to give effect to such a provision.

subsection.content: Subsection (1) applies to a provision for conferring benefits on persons of a particular racial group (disregarding any benefits to persons of another racial group which are exceptional or relatively insignificant), being a provision which is contained in a charitable instrument.

subsection.leadIn: In applying this section—
subsection.def: charitable instrument (慈善文書) means an enactment or other instrument so far as it relates to charitable purposes;
charitable purposes (慈善目的) means purposes which are exclusively charitable according to any enactment or rule of law.

subsection.leadIn: Nothing in Part 3, 4 or 5 renders unlawful any act done in relation to particular work by any person in, or in connection with—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: affording only persons of a particular racial group access to facilities for training which would help to fit them for that work; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: encouraging only persons of a particular racial group to take advantage of opportunities for doing that work,

subsection.continued: where it reasonably appears to that person that at any time within the 12 months immediately preceding the doing of the act—

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: there were no persons of the racial group concerned doing that work in Hong Kong; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the number of persons of that racial group doing the work in Hong Kong was comparatively small.

subsection.content: Subsection (1) does not apply in relation to any discrimination that is rendered unlawful by section 10.

section.name: s52
section.heading: Discriminatory training by employers, organizations of workers or employers or professional or trade organizations, etc.

subsection.leadIn: Nothing in Part 3, 4 or 5 renders unlawful any act done by an employer in relation to a particular work in his or her employment at a particular establishment in Hong Kong, being an act done in, or in connection with—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: affording only those of his or her employees working at that establishment who are of a particular racial group access to facilities for training which would help to fit them for that work; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: encouraging only persons of a particular racial group to take advantage of opportunities for doing that work at that establishment,

subsection.continued: where at any time within the 12 months immediately preceding the doing of the act—

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: there were no persons of the racial group concerned among those doing that work at that establishment; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the number of persons of that racial group among those doing that work was comparatively small.

subsection.leadIn: Nothing in section 18 renders unlawful any act done by an organization to which that section applies in, or in connection with—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: affording only members of the organization who are of a particular racial group access to facilities for training which would help to fit them for holding a post of any kind in the organization; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: encouraging only members of a particular racial group to take advantage of opportunities for holding such posts in the organization,

subsection.continued: where at any time within the 12 months immediately preceding the doing of the act—

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: there were no persons of the racial group concerned among persons holding such posts in the organization; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the number of persons of that racial group holding such posts was comparatively small.

subsection.leadIn: Nothing in Part 3, 4 or 5 renders unlawful any act done by an organization to which section 18 applies in, or in connection with, encouraging persons of a particular racial group to become members of the organization where at any time within the 12 months immediately preceding the doing of the act—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: no persons of the racial group were members of that organization; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the proportion of persons of the racial group among members of that organization was comparatively small.

subsection.leadIn: References in this Ordinance to the affording by any person of access to benefits, facilities or services—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: are not limited to benefits, facilities or services provided by that person himself or herself; but

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: include any means by which it is in that person’s power to facilitate access to benefits, facilities or services provided by any other person (actual provider).

subsection.content: Where by any provision of this Ordinance the affording by any person of access to benefits, facilities or services in a discriminatory way is in certain circumstances prevented from being unlawful, the effect of the provision is to extend also to the liability under this Ordinance of any actual provider.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is to be construed as affecting in any way any law concerning nationality, citizenship, resident status or naturalization; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: renders unlawful any act done by any person in, or in connection with, the operation of any such law.

section.name: s55
section.heading: Immigration legislation
section.content: Nothing in Part 3, 4 or 5 affects, as regards a person not having the right to enter and remain in Hong Kong, any immigration legislation governing entry into, stay in and departure from Hong Kong, or the application of any such legislation.

section.name: s56
section.heading: Acts done under statutory authority not affected by Parts 3, 4 and 5
section.content: Nothing in Part 3, 4 or 5 renders unlawful any act done by a person if it was necessary for that person to do it in order to comply with a requirement of an existing statutory provision.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: is to be construed as affecting the operation of any of the provisions of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the New Territories Ordinance (Cap. 97); or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the New Territories Leases (Extension) Ordinance (Cap. 150); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: renders unlawful any act done by any person in, or in connection with, the operation of any of those provisions.

subsection.content: No provision or Part of this Ordinance specified in column 2 of Schedule 5 renders unlawful any discrimination specified opposite thereto in column 3 of that Schedule.

subsection.leadIn: Nothing in Part 3, 4 or 5 renders unlawful any act done by any person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in connection with any discrimination which is not unlawful by virtue of the operation of subsection (1); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to the extent that it is done for the purposes of that discrimination.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: work towards the elimination of discrimination;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: promote equality of opportunity and harmony between persons of different racial groups generally;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: work towards the elimination of harassment and vilification;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: in the case of any act alleged to be unlawful by virtue of this Ordinance, encourage persons who are concerned with the matter to which act relates to effect a settlement of the matter by conciliation, whether under section 78 or otherwise;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: keep under review the working of this Ordinance and when required to do so by the Chief Executive, or when it otherwise thinks fit, draw up and submit to the Chief Executive proposals for amending this Ordinance; and

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: perform such other functions as are imposed on it under this Ordinance or any other enactment.

subsection.content: The Commission may do all such things as are necessary for, or incidental or conducive to, the better performance of its functions.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting subsection (1), the Commission may in particular—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: with the prior approval of the Chief Executive, become a member of or affiliate to any international body concerned (whether in whole or in part) with the elimination of discrimination; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: exercise such powers as are conferred on it under this Ordinance.

subsection.content: Without limiting section 59(1), the Commission, pursuant to its powers under paragraphs (a) and (b) of that section, shall keep Schedule 5 under review.
Whenever the Commission thinks it necessary, it shall draw up and submit to the Chief Executive proposals for amending Schedule 5.

section.name: s61
section.heading: Restrictions on delegation by Commission
section.leadIn: The Commission may not under section 67(1) of the Sex Discrimination Ordinance (Cap. 480) delegate any of its functions or powers under—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: section 82;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any provisions of any regulations made under section 83 which are specified in the regulations as provisions which are not subject to section 67 of the Sex Discrimination Ordinance (Cap. 480); or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any provisions of any rules made under section 82 which are specified in the rules as provisions which are not subject to that section 67.

section.name: s62
section.heading: Protection of members of Commission, etc.

subsection.content: No person to whom this subsection applies, acting in good faith, is personally liable in damages for any act done or default made in the performance or purported performance of any function, or the exercise or purported exercise of any power, imposed or conferred on the Commission under this Ordinance.

The protection conferred by subsection (1) on any person to whom that subsection applies in respect of any act or default does not in any way affect the liability of the Commission for that act or default.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1) applies to the following persons— (Amended 18 of 2014 s. 41)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a member of the Commission or a committee;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an employee of the Commission;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a conciliator.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission may issue codes of practice containing such practical guidance as it thinks fit for the purposes of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the elimination of discrimination;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the promotion of equality of opportunity and harmony between persons of different racial groups; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the elimination of harassment and vilification.

subsection.content: When the Commission proposes to issue a code of practice, it shall prepare and publish (otherwise than in the Gazette) the code; it shall consider any representations made to it about the code and may modify the code accordingly.

In the course of preparing any code of practice for eventual publication under subsection (2), the Commission shall consult such associations, organizations, associations of organizations or bodies as appear to the Commission to be appropriate including any associations, organizations, associations of organizations or bodies specified by the Secretary for Constitutional and Mainland Affairs by notice published in the Gazette.

subsection.leadIn: If the Commission determines to proceed with a code of practice published under subsection (2), it shall cause the code to be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: published in the Gazette; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: laid on the table of the Legislative Council at the next sitting after its publication in the Gazette.

subsection.content: The Legislative Council may, by resolution passed at a sitting of the Legislative Council held not later than 28 days after the sitting at which a code of practice is laid on the table of that Council (the relevant period), provide that the code of practice shall be amended in any manner consistent with this section.

If the relevant period would but for this section expire after the end of a session or a dissolution of the Legislative Council, but on or before the day of its second sitting in the next session, the period for amending the code is deemed to be extended and expire on the day after that second sitting.

The Legislative Council may, before the expiration of the relevant period, by resolution extend the period for amending the code of practice to the first sitting of that Council held not earlier than the twenty-first day after the day of such expiration.

Where the relevant period is extended under subsection (6), the Legislative Council may, before the expiration of the extended period, by resolution extend that extended period to the first sitting of that Council held not earlier than the twenty-first day after the day of the second sitting in the next session referred to in that subsection.

A resolution passed by the Legislative Council in accordance with this section shall be published in the Gazette not later than 14 days after the passing of the resolution or within such further period as the Chief Executive may allow in a particular case.

subsection.leadIn: A code of practice shall come into operation—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if on the expiration of the relevant period or that period as extended under subsection (6), (7) or (8), the Legislative Council has not passed a resolution amending the code of practice, on the expiration of the relevant period or that period as so extended (as the case may be); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the Legislative Council passes a resolution amending the code of practice, at midnight on the day before the day on which the resolution is published in the Gazette.

subsection.content: A code of practice may contain such transitional provisions or savings as appear to the Commission to be necessary or expedient in connection with the matters which are the subject of the code.

The Commission may from time to time revise the whole or any part of a code of practice and issue the revised code, and subsections (2), (3), (4), (5), (6), (7), (8), (9), (10) and (11) apply (with appropriate modifications) to a revised code.

Without limiting subsection (1), a code of practice may include such practical guidance as the Commission thinks fit as to what steps it is reasonably practicable for employers to take for the purpose of preventing their employees from doing in the course of their employment acts made unlawful by this Ordinance.

A failure on the part of any person to observe any provision of a code of practice shall not of itself render the person liable to any proceedings; but in any proceedings under this Ordinance before any court any code of practice issued under this section shall be admissible in evidence, and if any provision of such a code appears to the court to be relevant to any question arising in the proceedings it shall be taken into account in determining that question.

subsection.def: In this section, sitting (會議), when used to calculate time, means the day on which the sitting commences and only includes a sitting at which subsidiary legislation is included in the order paper.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the Commission thinks fit, it may conduct a formal investigation for any purpose connected with the carrying out of any of its functions under that section; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if required by the Chief Secretary for Administration, the Commission shall conduct a formal investigation for any purpose connected with the carrying out of any of its functions under that section.

subsection.content: The Commission shall not embark on a formal investigation unless the requirements of this section have been complied with.

The terms of reference for the formal investigation are to be drawn up by the Commission or, where the Chief Secretary for Administration requires the Commission to conduct the investigation, by the Chief Secretary for Administration after consulting the Commission.

The Commission shall give general notice of the holding of the formal investigation unless the terms of reference confine it to activities of persons named in them, but in such a case the Commission shall in the prescribed manner give those persons notice of the holding of the investigation.

subsection.leadIn: Where the terms of reference of the formal investigation confine it to activities of persons named in them and the Commission in the course of the investigation proposes to investigate any act made unlawful by this Ordinance which it believes a person so named may have done, the Commission shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: inform that person of its belief and its proposal to investigate the act; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: offer that person an opportunity of making oral or written representations with regard to it (or both oral and written representations as that person thinks fit).

subsection.leadIn: A person who avails himself of an opportunity to make oral representations under subsection (4)(b) may be represented—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by counsel or a solicitor; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by some other person of the person’s choice, not being a person to whom the Commission objects on the ground that he or she is unsuitable.

subsection.content: The Commission may or, if the Commission was required by the Chief Secretary for Administration to conduct the formal investigation, the Chief Secretary for Administration after consulting the Commission may, from time to time, revise the terms of reference.
Subsections (1), (3), (4) and (5) apply to the revised investigation and terms of reference as they apply to the original.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of a formal investigation, the Commission, by a notice in the prescribed form served on a person in the prescribed manner, may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: require the person to furnish such written information as may be described in the notice;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: specify the time at which, and the manner and form in which, the information is to be furnished; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: require the person to attend at the time and place specified in the notice and give oral information about, and produce all documents in the person’s possession or control relating to, any matter specified in the notice.

subsection.leadIn: Except as provided in section 73, a notice may be served under subsection (1) only where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: service of the notice has been authorized in writing by or on behalf of the Chief Secretary for Administration; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the terms of reference of the formal investigation—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: state that the Commission believes that a person named in them may have done or may be doing all or any of the acts described in subsection (3); and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: confine the investigation to those acts.

subsection.leadIn: The acts referred to in subsection (2)(b)(i) are acts of the following descriptions—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: unlawful discriminatory acts;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: unlawful acts of harassment;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: contraventions of section 41, 42, 43, 44 or 45.

subsection.leadIn: A notice under subsection (1) may not require a person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to give information, or produce any documents, which the person could not be compelled to give in evidence, or produce, in civil proceedings before the Court of First Instance; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to attend at any place unless the necessary expenses of the person’s journey to and from that place are paid or tendered to him or her.

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person fails to comply with a notice served on that person under subsection (1); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Commission has reasonable cause to believe that that person intends not to comply with it,

subsection.continued: the Commission may apply to the District Court for an order requiring the person to comply with the notice or with such directions for the like purpose as may be contained in the order; and section 66A of the District Court Ordinance (Cap. 336) applies to failure without reasonable excuse to comply with any such order as it applies in the cases there provided.

subsection.leadIn: A person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: wilfully alters, suppresses, conceals or destroys a document which he or she has been required by a notice or order under this section to produce; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in complying with such a notice or order, knowingly or recklessly makes any statement which in a material respect is false or misleading,

subsection.continued: commits an offence.

subsection.content: A person who commits an offence under subsection (6) is liable on conviction to a fine at level 4.

section.name: s67
section.heading: Recommendations and reports on formal investigations

subsection.leadIn: If in the light of its findings in a formal investigation it appears to the Commission necessary or expedient, whether during the course of the investigation or after its conclusion—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to make to any persons, with a view to promoting equality of opportunity and harmony between persons of different racial groups who are affected by any of their activities, recommendations for changes in their policies or procedures, or as to any other matters; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to make to the Chief Secretary for Administration any recommendations, whether for changes in the law or otherwise,

subsection.continued: the Commission shall make those recommendations accordingly.

subsection.content: The Commission shall prepare a report of its findings in any formal investigation conducted by it.

subsection.leadIn: If the formal investigation is one required by the Chief Secretary for Administration, the following applies—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Commission shall deliver the report to the Chief Secretary for Administration;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Chief Secretary for Administration shall cause the report to be published in such manner as he or she thinks fit; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: unless required by the Chief Secretary for Administration, the Commission shall not publish the report.

subsection.content: If the formal investigation is not one required by the Chief Secretary for Administration, the Commission shall publish the report or make it available for inspection in accordance with subsection (5).

subsection.leadIn: Where under subsection (4) a report is to be made available for inspection, any person shall be entitled, on payment of a reasonable fee, if any, as may be determined by the Commission—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to inspect the report during ordinary office hours and take copies of the whole report or any part of it; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to obtain from the Commission a copy, certified by the Commission to be correct, of the report.

subsection.content: The Commission may, if it thinks fit, determine that the right conferred by subsection (5)(a) is exercisable in relation to a copy of the report, instead of, or in addition to, the original.
The Commission shall give general notice of the place or places where, and the times when, the report or a copy of it may be inspected.

subsection.leadIn: No information given to the Commission by any person (the informant) in connection with a formal investigation shall be disclosed by the Commission, any member of the Commission or a committee, any employee of the Commission, any conciliator, or any person who has been such a member, employee or conciliator, except—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on the order of any court;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: with the informant’s consent;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in the form of a summary or other general statement published by the Commission which does not identify the informant or any other person to whom the information relates;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: in a report of the investigation published by the Commission or made available for inspection under section 67(5);

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: to members of the Commission or a committee, employees of the Commission or conciliators or, so far as may be necessary for the proper performance of the functions of the Commission, to other persons; or

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: for the purpose of any civil proceedings under this Ordinance to which the Commission is a party, or any criminal proceedings.

subsection.content: Any person who discloses information in contravention of subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 4.

In preparing any report for publication or for inspection, the Commission shall exclude, so far as it is consistent with its functions and the object of the report, any matter which relates to the private affairs of any individual or business interests of any person where the publication of that matter might, in the opinion of the Commission, prejudicially affect that individual or person.

part.name: P8
part.heading: Enforcement

section.name: s69
section.heading: Restrictions on proceedings for contravention of Ordinance

subsection.content: Except as otherwise provided by this Ordinance, no proceedings, whether civil or criminal, lie against any person in respect of an act by reason that the act is unlawful by virtue of a provision of this Ordinance.
Subsection (1) does not preclude the making of an order of certiorari, mandamus or prohibition.

section.name: s70
section.heading: Claims in respect of discrimination, harassment and vilification

subsection.leadIn: A claim by or on behalf of any person (the claimant) that another person (the respondent)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has committed an act of discrimination against the claimant which is unlawful by virtue of Part 3 or 4;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has committed an act of harassment against the claimant which is unlawful by virtue of Part 3 or 4;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: has committed an act which is unlawful by virtue of section 45; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: is to be treated, by virtue of section 47, 47A or 48, as having committed an act of discrimination or harassment referred to in paragraph (a) or (b) against the claimant or an act referred to in paragraph (c), (Amended 8 of 2020 s. 34)

subsection.continued: may be made the subject of civil proceedings in like manner as any other claim in tort.

subsection.content: Subsection (1) does not apply to a claim under section 19(1) of an act in respect of which an appeal, or proceedings in the nature of an appeal, may be brought under any enactment.

Proceedings under subsection (1) are to be brought in the District Court but all such remedies shall be obtainable in such proceedings as, apart from this subsection and section 69(1), would be obtainable in the Court of First Instance.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting the power conferred by subsection (3), the District Court may—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: order that the respondent shall perform any reasonable act or course of conduct to redress any loss or damage suffered by the claimant;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: order that the respondent shall employ or re-employ the claimant;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: order that the respondent shall promote the claimant;

paragraph.name: e
f
paragraph.content: order that the respondent shall pay to the claimant punitive or exemplary damages; or

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: make an order declaring void in whole or in part and either ab initio or from such date as may be specified in the order, any contract or agreement made in contravention of this Ordinance.

subsection.content: By virtue of this subsection and notwithstanding any law, the District Court has jurisdiction to hear and determine any proceedings under subsection (1) and has all such powers as are necessary or expedient for it to have in order to provide, grant or make any remedy, injunction or order mentioned in this Ordinance.

In respect of an unlawful act of discrimination falling within section 4(1)(b), no award of damages is to be made if the respondent proves that the requirement or condition concerned was not applied with the intention of treating the claimant unfavourably on the ground of the race of the claimant.

subsection.name: 6A
subsection.content: Subsection (6) does not apply in relation to an unlawful act of discrimination falling within section 4(1)(b) that is committed on or after the commencement date* of Part 9 of the Discrimination Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Ordinance 2020 (8 of 2020). (Added 8 of 2020 s. 44)

For the avoidance of doubt, it is declared that damages in respect of an unlawful act of discrimination or harassment, or an act which is unlawful by virtue of section 45, may include compensation for injury to feelings whether or not they include compensation under any other head.

subsection.leadIn: This section applies to any act which is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an unlawful discriminatory act;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an unlawful act of harassment;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a contravention of section 41; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a contravention of section 42, 43, 44 or 45,

subsection.continued: and so applies whether or not the proceedings have been brought in respect of the act.

subsection.leadIn: If in the course of a formal investigation the Commission becomes satisfied that a person is committing, or has committed, any acts to which this section applies, the Commission may in the prescribed manner serve on the person a notice in the prescribed form requiring the person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: not to commit any such acts (which may include discontinuing or changing any of the person’s practices or other arrangements which occasioned those acts, in particular to avoid any repetition thereof); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: where compliance with paragraph (a) involves changes in any of the person’s practices or other arrangements—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: to inform the Commission that he or she has effected changes and what those changes are; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: to take such steps as may be reasonably required by the notice for the purpose of affording that information to other persons concerned.

subsection.content: An enforcement notice may also require the person on whom it is served to furnish the Commission with such other information as may be reasonably required by the notice in order to verify that the notice has been complied with.

An enforcement notice may specify the time at which, and the manner and form in which, any information is to be furnished to the Commission, but the time at which any information is to be furnished in compliance with the notice must not be later than 5 years after the notice has become final.

Section 66(5) applies to requirements under subsections (2)(b), (3) and (4) contained in an enforcement notice which has become final as it applies to requirements in a notice served under section 66(1).
Not later than 45 days after an enforcement notice is served on any person, he or she may appeal to the District Court against any requirement in the notice.

Where the District Court considers a requirement in respect of which an appeal is brought under subsection (1) to be unreasonable because it is based on an incorrect finding of fact or for any other reason, the Court shall quash the requirement.

On quashing a requirement under subsection (2), the District Court may direct that the enforcement notice shall be treated as if, in place of the requirement quashed, it had contained a requirement in terms specified in the direction.
Subsection (1) does not apply to a requirement treated as included in an enforcement notice by virtue of a direction under subsection (3).

section.name: s73
section.heading: Investigation as to compliance with enforcement notice

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the terms of reference of a formal investigation state that its purpose is to determine whether any requirements of an enforcement notice are being or have been carried out, but section 66(2)(b) does not apply; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: section 65(3) is complied with in relation to the investigation on a date (commencement date) not later than the expiration of the period of 5 years beginning when the enforcement notice became final,

subsection.continued: the Commission may within the relevant period serve notices under section 66(1) for the purposes of the investigation without needing to obtain the consent of the Chief Secretary for Administration.

def.name: RelevantPeriod
def.leadIn: In subsection (1), relevant period (有關期間) means the period beginning on the commencement date and ending on the later of the following dates—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the date on which the period of 5 years referred to in subsection (1)(b) expires;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the date 2 years after the commencement date.

subsection.content: The Commission shall establish and maintain a register (the register) of enforcement notices which have become final.

subsection.leadIn: A person is entitled, on payment of a reasonable fee, if any, as may be determined by the Commission—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to inspect the register during ordinary office hours and take copies of any entry; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to obtain from the Commission a copy, certified by the Commission to be correct, of any entry in the register.

subsection.content: The Commission may, if it thinks fit, determine that the right conferred by subsection (2)(a) is exercisable in relation to a copy of the register, instead of, or in addition to, the original.
The Commission shall give general notice of the place or places where, and the times when, the register or a copy of it may be inspected.

section.name: s75
section.heading: Persistent discrimination, harassment or vilification
section.leadIn: If, during the period of 5 years beginning on the date on which either of the following became final in the case of any person, namely—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an enforcement notice served on the person;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: a finding by the District Court that the person has done—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: an unlawful discriminatory act;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: an unlawful act of harassment; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: an act contravening section 45,

section.continued: it appears to the Commission that unless restrained the person is likely to do one or more acts falling within paragraph (b), or contravening section 41, the Commission may apply to the District Court for an injunction restraining the person from doing so; and the District Court, if satisfied that the application is well-founded, may grant the injunction in the terms applied for or in more limited terms.

subsection.content: Proceedings in respect of a contravention of section 42, 43 or 44 may be brought only by the Commission and in accordance with this section.

subsection.leadIn: The proceedings must be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an application for a decision whether the alleged contravention occurred; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an application under subsection (4),

subsection.continued: or both.

subsection.content: An application under subsection (2)(a) must be made to the District Court.

subsection.leadIn: If it appears to the Commission—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that a person has done an act which by virtue of section 42, 43 or 44 was unlawful; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that unless restrained the person is likely to do further acts which by virtue of that section are unlawful,

subsection.continued: the Commission may apply to the District Court for an injunction restraining the person from doing so; and the District Court, if satisfied that the application is well-founded, may grant the injunction in the terms applied for or in more limited terms.

subsection.content: Without prejudice to subsection (4), if it appears to the Commission that a person has done an act which was unlawful by virtue of section 42, the Commission may apply to the District Court for an order imposing a financial penalty on such person; and the District Court, if satisfied that the application is well-founded, may make such an order.

The financial penalty imposed under subsection (5) shall not exceed $10,000 for the first occasion on which a penalty is imposed, and $30,000 for the second and any subsequent occasion on which a penalty is imposed in respect of that person.

part.crossHeading: Help for Persons Suffering Discrimination, Harassment or Vilification

section.name: s77
section.heading: Help for aggrieved persons in obtaining information, etc.

subsection.leadIn: With a view to helping a person (the person aggrieved) who considers he or she may have been discriminated against or harassed in contravention of this Ordinance, or the subject of an unlawful act under section 45—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to decide whether to institute proceedings; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the person does so, to formulate and present his or her case in the most effective manner,

subsection.continued: the Commission may prescribe—

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: forms by which the person aggrieved may question the respondent on the respondent’s reasons for doing any relevant act, or on any other matter which is or may be relevant; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: forms by which the respondent may if he or she so wishes reply to any questions.

subsection.leadIn: Where the person aggrieved questions the respondent (whether or not in accordance with a form referred to in subsection (1))—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the question, and any reply by the respondent (whether or not in accordance with such a form) is, subject to subsections (3), (4) and (5), admissible as evidence in the proceedings; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if it appears to the District Court that the respondent deliberately, and without reasonable excuse, omitted to reply within a reasonable period or that the respondent’s reply is evasive or equivocal, the Court may draw any inference from that fact it considers it just and equitable to draw, including an inference that the respondent committed an unlawful act.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: prescribe the period within which questions must be served in order to be admissible under subsection (2)(a); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: prescribe the manner in which a question, and any reply by the respondent, may be served.

subsection.content: Rules under the District Court Ordinance (Cap. 336) may enable the District Court entertaining a claim under section 70 to determine, before the date fixed for the hearing of the claim, whether a question or reply is admissible under this section or not.

This section is without prejudice to any other enactment or rule of law regulating interlocutory and preliminary matters in proceedings before the District Court, and has effect subject to any enactment or rule of law regulating the admissibility of evidence in such proceedings.

subsection.def: In this section, respondent (答辯人) includes a prospective respondent.

subsection.content: A person may lodge with the Commission a complaint in writing alleging that another person has done an act which is unlawful by virtue of a provision of this Ordinance.
A representative complaint may be lodged under subsection (1) in accordance with rules made under section 82.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (4), where a complaint is lodged under subsection (1), the Commission shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: conduct an investigation into the act the subject of the complaint; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: endeavour, by conciliation, to effect a settlement of the matter to which the act relates.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission may decide not to conduct, or to discontinue, an investigation into an act the subject of a complaint lodged under subsection (1) if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: it is satisfied that the act is not unlawful by reason of a provision of this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it is of the opinion that the person aggrieved by the act does not desire (or, in a case to which subsection (2) applies, none of the persons aggrieved by the act desires) that the investigation be conducted or continued;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a period of more than 12 months has elapsed beginning when the act was done;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: in a case to which subsection (2) applies, it determines, in accordance with rules made under section 82, that the complaint should not be a representative complaint; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: it is of the opinion that the complaint is frivolous, vexatious, misconceived or lacking in substance.

subsection.leadIn: Where the Commission decides not to conduct, or to discontinue, an investigation into an act the subject of a complaint lodged under subsection (1), it shall by notice served on the person who lodged the complaint advise the person of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that decision; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the reason for that decision.

subsection.content: Evidence of anything said or done by any person in the course of conciliation under this section (including anything said or done at any conference held for the purposes of such conciliation) is not admissible in evidence in any proceedings under this Ordinance except with the consent of that person.

subsection.leadIn: For the avoidance of doubt, it is declared that subsection (6) does not apply where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a complaint is lodged under subsection (1); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a settlement has been effected of the matter to which the act the subject of the complaint relates.

section.name: s79
section.heading: Assistance other than by way of conciliation

subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a complaint has been lodged under section 78(1); but

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for whatever reason, there has not been a settlement of the matter to which the act the subject of the complaint relates,

subsection.continued: then any person who may institute proceedings under this Ordinance in respect of that act may make an application to the Commission for assistance in respect of those proceedings.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission shall consider an application under subsection (1) and may grant it if it thinks fit to do so, in particular where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the case raises a question of principle; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it is unreasonable, having regard to the complexity of the case or the applicant’s position in relation to the respondent or another person involved or any other matter, to expect the applicant to deal with the case unaided.

subsection.leadIn: Assistance by the Commission under this section may include—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: giving advice;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: arranging for the giving of advice or assistance by a solicitor or counsel;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: arranging for representation by any person including all such assistance as is usually given by a solicitor or counsel in the steps preliminary or incidental to any proceedings, or in arriving at or giving effect to a compromise to avoid or bring to an end any proceedings;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any other form of assistance which the Commission may consider appropriate,

subsection.continued: but paragraph (c) does not affect the law and practice regulating the descriptions of persons who may appear in, conduct, defend and address a court in, any proceedings except to the extent permitted under rules made in accordance with section 73E of the District Court Ordinance (Cap. 336).

subsection.leadIn: In so far as expenses are incurred by the Commission in providing the applicant with assistance under this section the recovery of those expenses (as taxed or assessed in such manner as may be prescribed by relevant rules) constitutes a first charge for the benefit of the Commission—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on any costs or expenses which (whether by virtue of a judgment or order of the District Court or an agreement or otherwise) are payable to the applicant by any other person in respect of the matter in connection with which the assistance is given; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: so far as relates to any costs or expenses, on his or her rights under any compromise or settlement arrived at in connection with that matter to avoid or bring to an end any proceedings.

subsection.content: The charge conferred by subsection (4) is subject to any charge under the Legal Aid Ordinance (Cap. 91) and to any provision in that Ordinance for payment of any sum into the Supplementary Legal Aid Fund established under that Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: relevant rules (有關規則) means any rules made under the District Court Ordinance (Cap. 336);
respondent (答辯人) includes a prospective respondent.

part.crossHeading: Period within which Proceedings to be Brought

section.name: s80
section.heading: Period within which proceedings to be brought

subsection.leadIn: The District Court shall not consider a claim under section 70 unless proceedings in respect of the claim are instituted within the period of 24 months beginning—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: when the act complained of was done; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if there is a relevant report in relation to that act, with the day on which the report is published or made available for inspection under section 67,

subsection.continued: whichever is the later.

subsection.leadIn: The District Court—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: shall not consider an application under section 76(2)(a) unless it is made within the period of 24 months beginning when the act to which it relates was done; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: shall not consider an application under section 76(4) unless it is made within the period of 5 years so beginning.

subsection.content: For the purposes of determining the period under subsection (1) within which proceedings may be brought, where an act to which the claim relates was the subject of a complaint lodged under section 78(1), then the period that elapsed between the date when the complaint was lodged and the date when the complaint was disposed of under section 78(3) or (4), as certified in writing by the Commission, shall be disregarded.

Notwithstanding subsections (1) and (2), the District Court may consider any claim or application which is out of time, if, in all the circumstances of the case, it considers that it is just and equitable to do so.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (4), the circumstances of the case include, in relation to any claim—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: whether the act to which the claim relates was the subject of a complaint lodged under section 78(1); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if so, the period that elapsed between when the act was done and when that complaint was so lodged.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this section—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where the inclusion of any term in a contract renders the making of the contract an unlawful act, that act shall be treated as extending throughout the duration of the contract;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any act extending over a period shall be treated as done at the end of that period; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a deliberate omission shall be treated as done when the person concerned decided upon it.

subsection.leadIn: In the absence of evidence to the contrary, a person shall be taken for the purposes of this section to decide upon an omission, that is deciding upon omitting to do an act (relevant act)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: when the person does an act inconsistent with doing the relevant act; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the person has done no such inconsistent act, when the period expires within which he or she might reasonably have been expected to do the relevant act if it were to be done.

subsection.content: The Chief Executive in Council may, by notice published in the Gazette, amend subsection (1) by substituting a longer period for the period specified in that subsection.

def.name: RelevantReport
def.leadIn: In this section, relevant report (有關報告), in relation to an act referred to in subsection (1), means a report—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: published or made available for inspection under section 67; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: from which it can reasonably be construed (whether or not the report mentions the act or the report was in any way prepared in consequence of the act) that the Commission is of the opinion that the act, or the class of acts to which the act belongs, is unlawful under a provision of Part 3, 4 or 5.

subsection.leadIn: A term of a contract is void where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: its inclusion renders the making of the contract unlawful by virtue of this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it is included in furtherance of an act rendered unlawful by this Ordinance; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: it provides for the doing of an act which would be rendered unlawful by this Ordinance.

subsection.content: Subsection (1) does not apply to a term the inclusion of which constitutes, or is in furtherance of, or provides for, unlawful discrimination against a party to the contract, but the term shall be unenforceable against that party.
A term in a contract which purports to exclude or limit any provision of this Ordinance is unenforceable by any person in whose favour the term would operate apart from this subsection.
Subsection (3) does not apply to a contract settling a claim to which section 70 applies.

subsection.leadIn: On the application of any person interested in a contract to which subsection (2) applies, the District Court may make such order as it thinks just for removing or modifying any term made unenforceable by that subsection; but such an order shall not be made unless all persons affected—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: have been given notice of the application (except where under rules made under the District Court Ordinance (Cap. 336) notice may be dispensed with); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: have been afforded an opportunity to make representations to the Court.

subsection.content: An order under subsection (5) may include provision as respects any period before making the order.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission may make rules—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: prescribing the persons, or persons belonging to a class of persons, who may lodge a representative complaint under section 78(1);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: prescribing the bodies and positions for the purposes of section 34;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: prescribing the matters to be taken into account by the Commission for the purposes of a determination under section 78(4)(d);

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: to enable the Commission to require such persons, or persons belonging to such class of persons, as are specified in the rules to furnish information to the Commission for the purposes of section 78;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: restricting the disclosure of any information referred to in paragraph (d) furnished to the Commission;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: to enable the Commission to direct persons to attend any conference held for the purposes of section 78;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: regulating the procedure of any conference held for the purposes of section 78;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: prescribing any other thing that is required or permitted to be prescribed under this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: Any rules made under subsection (1) may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: make different provisions for different circumstances and provide for a particular case or class of cases;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: be made so as to apply only in such circumstances as are prescribed by the rules;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: specify forms for the purposes of the rules;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: be made generally for the better or more effectual carrying out of the provisions of this Ordinance, including incidental, consequential, evidential and supplemental provisions.

subsection.content: Any rules made under this section may prescribe offences in respect of contraventions of the rules, and may provide for the imposition of a fine not exceeding level 4 and of imprisonment for a period not exceeding 2 years.

section.name: s83
section.heading: Regulations to empower Commission to bring certain proceedings

subsection.leadIn: The Secretary for Constitutional and Mainland Affairs may make regulations—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where any person may bring proceedings under section 70 but has not done so, empowering the Commission, in such circumstances as are specified in the regulations, to bring and maintain those proceedings as if the Commission were that person;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: specifying which of the remedies referred to in section 70(3) shall be obtainable by the Commission in any such proceedings;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: for the purposes of enabling the Commission to bring and maintain any such proceedings (including any related purposes), specifying modifications to which any provisions of this Ordinance (including any subsidiary legislation) shall be read.

subsection.content: Any regulations made under this section shall be subject to the approval of the Legislative Council.

This section is without prejudice to the Commission’s power to bring proceedings by way of judicial review, in relation to this Ordinance or any other law, pursuant to its functions under section 59(1).

The Chief Executive in Council may, by notice published in the Gazette, amend Schedule 1, 2, 3, 4 or 5 but any notice to amend Schedule 2, 3, 4 or 5 shall be subject to the approval of the Legislative Council. (Amended 8 of 2020 s. 16)
The Secretary for Constitutional and Mainland Affairs may, by notice published in the Gazette, amend Schedule 6. (Added 8 of 2020 s. 16)

section.name: s1
section.content: An employee specified in section 2, 3, 4, 5 or 6 is an employee in an existing employment for the purposes of section 14 of this Ordinance.

section.name: s2
section.leadIn: An employee specified in this section is an employee (other than a public officer or specified English teacher) of an employer where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the employee—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: began his or her employment with the employer pursuant to an offer of employment made to him or her before the commencement date*; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: continues to be employed by the employer without a break in service since he or she began service pursuant to the offer; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the employee is employed by the employer following one or more transfers of employment, all being transfers within the same group of companies within the meaning of section 13(3)(b) of this Ordinance, where the employment immediately preceding the first transfer was pursuant to an offer of employment made to him or her before the commencement date* and there is no break in the employee’s service since he or she began his or her employment pursuant to the offer.

section.name: s3
section.leadIn: An employee specified in this section is a judicial officer—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: who—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: began serving as a judicial officer pursuant to an offer of employment made to him or her before 27 November 1997; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: continues to serve as such officer without a break in service since he or she began service pursuant to the offer; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: who—

subparagraph.name: i
ii
subparagraph.content: had continued to serve as a public officer without a break in service since he or she began service pursuant to the offer and until he or she began serving as a judicial officer; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: continues to serve as a judicial officer without a break in service since beginning serving as such.

section.name: s4
section.leadIn: An employee specified in this section is an ICAC officer—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: who—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: began serving as an ICAC officer pursuant to an offer of employment made to him or her before 1 January 1999; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: continues to serve as such officer without a break in service since he or she began service pursuant to the offer; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: who—

subparagraph.name: i
ii
subparagraph.content: had continued to serve as a public officer without a break in service since he or she began service pursuant to the offer and until he or she began serving as an ICAC officer; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: continues to serve as an ICAC officer without a break in service since beginning serving as such.

section.name: s5
section.leadIn: An employee specified in this section is a public officer (other than a judicial officer or an ICAC officer) who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: began serving as such officer pursuant to an offer of employment made to him or her before 1 January 1999; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: continues to serve as such officer without a break in service since he or she began service pursuant to the offer.

section.name: s6
section.leadIn: An employee specified in this section is a specified English teacher who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: began his or her employment as such pursuant to an offer of employment made to him or her before the commencement date*; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: continues to be employed as such without a break in service since he or she began service pursuant to the offer.

section.name: s7
section.content: An employee (other than a public officer or specified English teacher) who is an employee specified in section 2 remains an employee so specified, whether or not the employment of the employee by the employer concerned, or (where section 2(b) applies) by any of the employers within the group of companies concerned, was or is pursuant to any extension, any renewal or re-engagement after termination and whether or not the employee was or has been promoted.

section.name: s8
section.content: A judicial officer, an ICAC officer or any other public officer, who is an employee specified in section 3, 4 or 5 remains an employee so specified, whether or not the service of the officer was or is pursuant to any extension, any renewal or re-engagement after termination and whether or not the officer was or has been promoted.

section.name: s9
section.leadIn: A specified English teacher who is an employee specified in section 6 remains an employee so specified whether or not the service of the specified English teacher was or is pursuant to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any extension, any renewal or re-engagement after termination; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any transfer from one primary or secondary school to another, or from a primary or secondary school to the Native-speaking English Teacher Section of the Education Bureau or vice versa.

section.name: s10
section.content: Provisions of this Schedule apply irrespective of whether or not an employee is or has become a Hong Kong permanent resident.

section.name: s11
section.leadIn: For the purposes of this Ordinance—
section.def: ICAC officer (廉署人員) means a public officer who is an officer within the meaning of section 2 of the Independent Commission Against Corruption Ordinance (Cap. 204);
judicial officer (司法人員) means a judicial officer holding a judicial office specified in Schedule 1 to the Judicial Officers Recommendation Commission Ordinance (Cap. 92);

def.name: LocalTermsOfEmployment,OverseasTermsOfEmployment
def.leadIn: local terms of employment (本地僱用條款) and overseas terms of employment (海外僱用條款)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: in relation to any employee (other than a public officer), mean respectively—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: such conditions or terms of service as apply, from time to time, primarily to the appointment or employment by the employer concerned of a person who is a Hong Kong permanent resident; and

subparagraph.name: ii

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in relation to a judicial officer, an ICAC officer or any other public officer, respectively mean the local conditions or terms of service and overseas conditions or terms of service within the meaning of such regulations, administrative rules, circulars and circular memoranda as apply, from time to time, generally to the appointment or employment of judicial officers, ICAC officers or other public officers (as the case may be);

def.name: PublicOfficer
def.leadIn: public officer (公職人員) does not include a specified English teacher who is employed—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in a primary or secondary school entirely maintained and controlled by the Government; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the Native-speaking English Teacher Section of the Education Bureau;

def.name: SpecifiedEnglishTeacher
def.leadIn: specified English teacher (指明英語教師) means a teacher—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: who is a native-speaker of English or possesses native-speaker English competency;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: who is normally first recruited from a place outside Hong Kong; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: who—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: is employed in a secondary school under the “Enhanced Native-speaking English Teacher Scheme” administered by the Education Bureau;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: is employed in a primary school under the “Native-speaking English Teacher Scheme” administered by that Bureau; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: is employed as an Advisory Teacher or a Regional Native-speaking English Teacher Coordinator in the Native-speaking English Teacher Section of that Bureau. (Amended E.R. 5 of 2018)
